turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What time does school start around here?

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: Nine o' clock.  Oh, I'm late! Maybe I'll see you later.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah. Maybe so.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: George! He's supposed to ask you to the dance!

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: But he didn't ask me.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: But he does! Don't you see?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: He comes out of the cafeteria line, he's nervous, he spills his corn, and he asks you to the dance!

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: Marty, you haven't been listening. Nobody's asked me to the dance...yet.

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: Hi, Marty!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Listen,  Professor Brown told me you called last night and gave me your message...

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: Are you all right, Marty? You seem a little...nervous.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, no, I'm fine...fine.

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: I'm usually nervous myself on first dates...but not tonight. It's funny, but somehow, I feel like....like I know you.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Uh, yeah, well, believe me, I sure feel like I know you!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, Eileen...jeez, that's hard for me to say. Have you ever been in a situation where -- well -- you know you have to act a certain way, but when you get there, you don't know if you can go through with it?

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: You mean like how you're supposed to act with someone on a first date?

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: I think I know exactly what you mean.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: Now, George! Dinner's ready now!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Coming, Eileen...

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: By the way, that reminds me...  Saturday night we're taking Grandma Stella out for Chinese food.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Eileen, Chinese food again?

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: George, if you don't want Chinese food, pick a place you want to go and make a reservation.

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: Is that what you were going to ask me, George? To go to the dance?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Uh, hi, Eileen.

turns.speaker: EILEEN
turns.text: How are you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh -- I'm all right. Say, listen, about this dance Saturday night --

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Dad, you seen the drill?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What drill?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: The drill!  The power drill I bought you for Christmas. I was using it last night.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Fine..

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Learn anything?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh yeah.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, Chinese food is fine.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Saturday night's the 'Springtime in Paris' dance. I'm taking Suzy Parker.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: The sunrise? What for?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Jeez, what do you think? To see it!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You've gotta ask her to the dance!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Not now....

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: George, she's beautiful, right? She's nice, she's decent, she's the kind of girl you'd like to marry, right? And there's nothing in the world you'd like more than to take her to that dance, right?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well... yeah...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Okay, then!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do I say?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Say what you were supposed to say in the cafeteria.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, no! That was for the cafeteria! This is different!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Christ, it's a miracle I was even born!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Nothing. Look, I'll write it down for you, okay?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What is that? A pencil that writes in ink?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It was Marty's turn to be confused. Huh?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Lemme see that.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: 'Bike fine point?'

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Bic... It's a Bic pen.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't want to hit you in the stomach!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You're not gonna hurt me. Just hit me in the stomach.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, Marty, I'm just not a fighter...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: How many times do I have to explain it to you?... We know you're not a fighter. You know it, I know it... but she doesn't know it. That's why we gotta make you look like a fighter, somebody who'll stand up for her, somebody who isn't chicken. And you're not gonna look like a fighter if you can't hit me in the stomach.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But I've never picked a fight in my entire life!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You're not picking a fight, you're coming to her rescue. Maybe we'd better go over the plan again. Where are you gonna be at 8:55?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm going to be at the dance.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: And where am I gonna be?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: In the parking lot, with her.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Okay. So right around 9:00 she's gonna get very angry with me -

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Why what?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Why is she gonna get angry with you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You mean, you're gonna --

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: George it's not your concern. Don't worry about it. Just remember that at 9:00, you'll be strolling through the parking lot and you'll see us -- struggling in the car, you'll run over, open the door and say....?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Your line, George!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh. Uh... 'Hey, you! Get your damn hands off her!'  George paused. You really think I should swear?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yes, definitely, god dammit George, swear. Then you hit me in the stomach, I go down for the count, and you and Eileen life happily ever after. Now, hit me in the stomach.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Maybe if I used my left....

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No, George, just concentrate on the anger. Anger.

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: You'd like to see a nuclear holocaust?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Not a holocaust --

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: Mr. McFly here wants to nuke it all, just so he can see it!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You know damn well that's not what I meant.

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: All I can say is, that's one helluva attitude, Mr. McFly. 'Let's explode a hundred megaton Geothermal nuclear device, just to see it.'

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, explode it up your ass!

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: Unfortunately, the way things are going, you may get your wish. You may see the entire annhiliation of the world. If not, you'll certainly see the destruction of all out natural resources. We can already see the air we breathe, not to mention the pollution in our rivers and lakes. We'll  see all of our oil reserves depleted, in fact, all of our energy sources. Yes, you people have a lot to look forward to -- a lot to see.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hey, Mr. Arky, gimme a break!  I'm seventeen years old! I'm not responsible for all these problems!

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: Yes, that's my name. Who are you, young man? Are you supposed to be here?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Uh -- yeah. I'm new here, and I'm supposed to be in this class.

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: You have a name?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Marty. Marty Lewis.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Who, me?

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: You're the only Mr. Lewis in this class.  If you have something to say, say it so the whole class can hear.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, yeah, I was thinking, if cars are gonna be going two or three hundred miles an hour, they're gonna be using an awful lot of gas. Like, what if we run out?

turns.speaker: MR. ARKY
turns.text: Run out of gas?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Operator...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Operator! Listen, this is an emergency! I have to make this call, but I don't have a dime -- all I got is a nickel -- but you gotta connect me --

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Sir, it only costs a nickel.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Local calls cost five cents. What number do you want?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh -- right! Uh, Madison 3489.

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Five cents, please.

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: I'm sorry, there's no answer.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Operator, what's today's date?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: March 11th.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What year?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Nineteen fifty --

turns.speaker: N.R.C. AGENT REESE
turns.text: Good evening, one said. Agents Reese   and Foley, from the Nuclear Regulatory Commition.  Mind stepping over here?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What's this all about?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What, am I radioactive or something?

turns.speaker: N.R.C. AGENT REESE
turns.text: No, no, not beyond an acceptable level. Have you been X-rayed recently, Martin?

turns.speaker: N.R.C. AGENT REESE
turns.text: Been any place unusual in the past twelve hours?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Home, school, here...

turns.speaker: N.R.C. AGENT REESE
turns.text: Okay, Martin. You have a good evening now.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah,  Right.

turns.speaker: N.R.C. AGENT REESE
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Pro! Release the rope!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor Brown! It's almost eight thirty -- I'm outta here!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Shhhhhhhh!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: The power of a million hydrogen bombs!  ...and we get twenty four measly volts. It's not fair! I've been working on this power converter since 1949, and you'd think in all that time, I could find the right chemicals that would efficiently convert radiation into electric energy! But no! Thirty three years of dedication and research, and all I've got to show for it is a bootleg video operation!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That reminds me, if we could scrape up enough for a 35 film chain, I've got a connection with a projectionist in a first run house -- we could be sellin' new movies on the street before they're even in the theater.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: A 35mm film chain... I'll see what I can do....

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Did you ever consider that some doors are locked for a reason?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Nope. The way I figure it, doors are made to be opened. See you after school.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Oh -- Marty -- what time did you say it was?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Eight thirty.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: AM or PM?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Pro, the sun's out!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Oh, right, right...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Jeez, for a guy with a ton of clocks, you sure don't pay much attention to time.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Catch you later!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: ...To be traveled through

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: But Professor --

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Get behind the shield! I'm about to release radiation!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: No, Marty. Shemp's molecular structure is completely intact!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Then where the hell is he?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: The appropriate question to ask is when the hell is he! You see, Shemp has just become the world's first time traveller. I've sent Shemp into the future -- two minutes into the future to be exact.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: The future? What are you talking about? Where's Shemp?!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Shemp is right here in this room...two minutes from now, and at exactly 9:02PM, we'll catch up to him.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Now hold on a minute, Professor! Hold the phone. Are you trying to tell me that this -- all of this here -- that this is -- it's a -- a --

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: A time machine! Because of that Coke?!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Precisely!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: The plutonium! That's what I came over here for! Professor, where did you get that stuff?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Exactly two minutes difference...  and it's still ticking!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Is Shemp all right?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Of course. Shemp is unaware that anything even happened, other than his stool suddenly falling over. We had to wait two minutes to catch up to him, but for Shemp the trip was instantaneous.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor, can this thing send Shemp back in time?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: A gold mine?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure! Listen -- we take the racing results from today's paper...

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Marty, that would alter history.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: So what? We'd be rich!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Don't you understand? The mere act of sending matter back in time would change the course of events, and changing history is a responsibility that I do not wish to bear.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: All I know is you're throwing away an awful lot of money.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: The future, Marty, the future is everything! I built this machine to see the future. So I am going to send Shemp twenty-four hours into the future. You can assist me, if you like.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure, he agreed quickly.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor? Professor Brown?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You know me?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor, you time machine works! It works! It sent me back in time! I'm from 1982!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Ssshhhhh!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: He will be. Simple inebriation, is all. The young man must have a rather low tolerance for alcohol... something that runs in the family. You see, he's a second cousin of mine on my mother's side. Came quite a distance to visit me, he added. His name's Lewis.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Marty.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Uh, Marty Lewis! I almost didn't recognize him -- haven't seen him in years.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Jeez -- this is where you used to live, huh? You must have been rich!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Must have been? Used to live? I do live here.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, yeah.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, there's a mall here now -- I mean, there will be.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: A mall?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, a shopping mall. You know, a shopping mall?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You've convinced me that you must be who you say you are. No living human has ever seen this machine.  But why? Why even in my twilight years would I remotely consider sending someone back in time?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You didn't, Professor. It was an accident! You see, what happened --

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: No! Don't tell me!  I don't want to know the future! My knowledge of future events... your mere presence here... could have devastating effects on the course of history. And altering history is a responsibility that I do not wish to bear. My immediate response is to send you back to your own time.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Pardon me?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh. That expression probably hasn't been invented yet... I can get behind -- I agree with you.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: On second thought, there may be some things you'll have to tell me.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: The power converter...

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Of course! The power converter! It works! Of course, it works...  What chemicals do we use?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, Professor, are you sure you want me to tell you? You know, changing the course of history and all....

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Blast it -- no, I suppose you're right.... You do know the proper chemical formula?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: How did you know?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Just a guess. I figured kids would still be drinking Coke in 1982.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor. Well, not exactly, Professor. You see, we don't point it at the sun.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: We don't....

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: 4200 rads...  That certainly can't be generated under controlled conditions in this day and age.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's just great!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You answered the door!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You were ringing the doorbell!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: I told you not to interfere with any of the events of this time! Nobody's supposed to see you here! What if I was a mailman? Or a salesman?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What if you lost your keys?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Then I would have figured out to get back in through the events in the natural course of history! Don't you understand? The fabric of history is very delicate. Anything you do could have serious consequences!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hey, look, gimme a break! All I did was answer the door! How's that gonna change history?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: I don't know, but I don't want to take any chances! Now you stay here and don't do anything. Don't answer the door, don't answer the phone, don't go outside. Understand?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Let me put it on a level you can understand. You don't belong here. You don't know anything about this world. You don't know the customs, you don't know how to talk, how to act -- you don't even look like you belong here. And if you walked out on the street, you wouldn't get 100 yards without being arrested. Then there would be questions, and where would we come up with the answers?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Okay, Professor, I get where you're coming from. The way I look, the way I'm dressed...  I'd stick out like a sore thumb.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: An atomic bomb.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor, be serious, would you?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: I am serious. If we could get you, the time machine, and the power converter in the vicinity of an atomic blast, we could send you back to the future.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You're talking crazy! An atomic blast would melt me and the time machine in a matter of seconds!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You forget -- time travel is instantaneous. The time machine would melt, but you would have already travelled through time. Of course, it's a moot point regardless. The only place atomic bombs are detonated is at the Army's Nevada Test Site, and those tests are kept absolutely top secret.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Say, where did this guitar come from?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh -- that -- I found it in the closet.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: I don't recall ever seeing it before.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, it was there.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Curious... Very curious....

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You did what?!?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Look, it's not a big deal! I can fix it! All I gotta do is get 'em together and make sure my old man asks her out!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You better make sure your old man asks her out, because if he doesn't, they may never have a first date. And if they don't have a first date, they won't have a second date. If they don't have a second date, they won't fall in love. If they don't fall in love, they won't get married, and if they don't get married, you'll never be born!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Where did you get this?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I brought it with me from 1982. It's from my science book.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: The test is this Monday! 15 megatons... Let's see, we need 4200 rads...  You'd have to be...exactly 800 yards from ground zero... You realize that what we're going to do could be extremely dangerous.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Believe me, Professor, running around on a nuclear test site can't be any more dangerous than what I've been doing.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Your 'mother' wanted me to tell you that she was very impressed by what you did this afternoon, and that if you were interested in going to the dance Saturday, she's available.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: But that's impossible!! George asked her out! He had to! I saw him walk her home! Oh, God!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: My guess is that she turned him down.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: But why? Why would she do that? She's supposed to marry the guy!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Apparently, what has happened is that the maternal instinct has transcended the gap of time and this has caused an alteration in your mother's emotional behavior.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Are you trying to tell me that my mother's got the hots for me?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: In a manner of speaking, yes. And because of that, she's no longer interested in your father.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Jesus!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's all taken care of.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Good. Professor Brown tested the tarp, noting in satisfaction that it was secure. I'll pick you up in front of the school at midnight. Don't be late -- we're cutting it close as it is. We've got a long drive ahead of us.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Look. I'm a little worried about this -- this whole thing with my mother, he admitted to the Professor. I mean, I don't know if I can do it -- I mean, hitting on my own mother, that's pretty heavy.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Nobody said anything about hitting her! You're just going to take a few liberties with her.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's exactly what I said! I mean, a guy and his mother -- that's illegal, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Look, Marty, she's not your mother yet. And if you don't go through with this, she may never be. I know it's hard, but there are some things we must do in life that are unpleasant. Some choices must be made that are difficult. Nonetheless, we must make them. Besides, this may be more than a simple question of your own existence, he added. The fate of the entire space-time continuum may rest on your shoulders . Marty tried to smile at him.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's just what I needed to hear.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: It'll be fine, Marty.  You'll be fine. Good luck. He stuck his hand out and Marty shook it. But there was still a question that was nagging at him...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor, if something does go wrong tonight... if I don't get my parents back together... when do you think I'd cease to exist?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: There's no way of knowing.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Perfect...

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: It could happen at the moment you arrive back in the future, theoretically, it could happen at the moment of your birth...or conception. Actually, it could happen at any time. It's a question to which I hope we'll never learn the answer.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You didn't?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Nope. My father's never clenched a fist in his entire life!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Curious...  Very curious.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It was sure nice of Uncle Sam to put those yardage markers up for us.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: We're at one and a half miles, so you're just a little over a mile from where you want to be,  Wait until minus 3 minutes before you go -- that should give you plenty of time, and it should be close enough to zero hour that they can't do anything to stop you. Park the truck at 800 and get in the refri-- the time chamber. Just be sure the nose of the truck is pointed at the bomb....the power converter will do the rest.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Thanks for everything, Pro.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Professor Brown grinned. I guess I'll see you in... about 30 years.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Marty,  I know I've repeatedly asked you not to tell me anything about the future, but....well, those loud bangs on the tape recorder....are they....

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Professor -- there are some doors that shouldn't be opened, Marty said softly, without turning around.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What year is this?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: 1982! March 18, just like we planned! My calculations were absolutely correct! Thirty years! God, I cannot believe it's been thirty years! Sure, it was a long time ago -- longest I've ever had to wait for the results of an experiment!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Hop in, Marty, . We've got a long drive ahead of us.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What do you call this?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: A car.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: You see, I never rebuilt the time machine after it was destroyed in 1952. I decided that experimenting with time and possibly changing history was too risky. Anyway, experiments in time travel were banned in all 87 states after the governor of Cuba caught Dr. Felstien fooling around in the Bermuda Triangle -- that was back in '64.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: 87 states? Time travel bans? What the hell?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: But if you didn't rebuild the time machine, how did I go back in time in the first place?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: According to your girlfriend, Suzy Parker, you and she were at the movies. You went to the restroom and you never came out. Obviously, you stepped through an inter-dimensional time warp, created by the original operation of the time machine.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Obviously!

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: But I told everyone your disappearance was due to a teleportation experiment you were helping me with. So don't mention anything about time travel to anyone.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What theater was I at?

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: The Orpheum.

turns.speaker: PROFESSOR EMMETT BROWN
turns.text: Pretty, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: It's the most beautiful city I've ever seen! What is it?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Uh, yeah... Gimme a Tab.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: A Tab.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Sweet and what?  Maybe you'd better pay for this first.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure,.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Look, maybe I'd better talk to Dick. Is he around?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Dick? Dick who?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Now who's being stupid? The guy who runs this place.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: I run this place!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What happened to Dick Wilson?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Dick Wilson? Dickie Wilson? Dickie Wilson runs this place? That's a laugh!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: ...He just lets himself get pushed around all the time! People walk all over him and he never fights back, never stands up for himself.

turns.speaker: SUZY
turns.text: No self confidence, I guess... At least you don't take after him.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah... Jesus! I wonder how he ever got up enough nerve to marry my mom.

turns.speaker: SUZY
turns.text: Can you imagine your parents in bed together?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No way!

turns.speaker: SUZY
turns.text: Me neither. I've always wondered whether they slept together before they got married. You think yours did?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hell no! The way my mom carries on about sex -- you even mention the word and she goes into cardiac arrest. You shoulda seen her face when I told her we were gonna stay up all night Saturday, he added. Always afraid something is going to happen.

turns.speaker: SUZY
turns.text: Is  something going to happen Saturday night?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Suzy!

turns.speaker: SUZY
turns.text: Hi, Marty!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What did you do to your hair?

turns.speaker: SUZY
turns.text: What did you do to yours?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Hi. where's Cato?

turns.speaker: KIT
turns.text: Well, he's gone.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Gone?... Where?

turns.speaker: KIT
turns.text: He said not to tell.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Oh yeah?

turns.speaker: KIT
turns.text: Yeah, he said for you to give us a lift into town. You're the ones with the Studebaker, aren't you?

turns.speaker: KIT
turns.text: No... You go in there, I'll have to kill you.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: KIT
turns.text: Can't afford to take chances.
